summary: The study investigates the influence of drug-polymer interactions on the release kinetics of PLGA and PLA/PEG nanoparticles (NPs) for controlled drug delivery. Key findings highlight that CURC-loaded PLGA NPs exhibit slower release rates and higher encapsulation efficiency due to hydrophobic interactions, making them suitable for controlled delivery in regenerative medicine.
methods: Microfluidic-based synthesis was used to prepare nano-sized carriers (PLGA NPs and PLA/PEG micelles) loaded with curcumin (CURC). The NPs were characterized for physical properties, drug loading, and release kinetics. Cytotoxicity and antimicrobial activity were also evaluated.
results: NPs had uniform size distribution with PDI ≤0.2. PLGA NPs showed a diameter (Dₕ) of 61.91 ± 1.86 nm and zeta potential (ζ) of 13.74 ± 0.97 mV. CURC loading was 2.81 ± 0.81 µg/mg for PLGA NPs and 2.51 ± 0.57 µg/mg for PLA/PEG micelles. CURC-loaded PLGA NPs exhibited slower release rates and higher encapsulation efficiency. No or slight cytotoxic effects were observed on NHDFs.
